title: The Intolerable Dr Peterson
description:
I look at the reactions in the wake of the Christchurch shooting, and how they are moving in the wrong directions.  Jordan Peterson's book was banned by Whitcoull's and Armin Navabi's Atheist event was cancelled at Mount Royal University

to read about the book banning of Jordan Peterson:
https://www.thepostmillennial.com/major-new-zealand-book-store-bans-jordan-petersons-book-in-shocking-act-of-censorship/

Armin's twitter documenting the events of the past few days:
@ArminNavabi
Follow me here:

twitter: @theother_95
Instagram: @theother95
Facebook: @theother95page

Email me: theotherninetyfive@gmail.com

transcript_parts.text: since the mosque massacre in
Christchurch New Zealand there have been
a number of reactions this week one of
them being the banning of assault rifles
throughout New Zealand I'm not going to
talk about that what I'm going to talk
about today is Jordan Peterson's 12
rules for life being banned from the
largest book chain in New Zealand the
store is called wit coals and here is a
customer service letter explaining why
the book is banned hello thank you for
contacting us unfortunately 12 rules for
life is currently unavailable which is a
decision that wit Kohl's has made in
light of some extremely disturbing
material being circulated prior during
and after the Christchurch attacks as a
business which takes our
responsibilities to our communities very
seriously we believe it would be wrong
to support the author at this time
okay so what does this mean this means
that 12 rules for life is being looked
at as something that contributed to the
massacre I find that very problematic
one because I've read the book and I've
watched Peterson's lectures where he
explains many of the points all of the
chapters highlight how do take
responsibility onto yourself rather than
blaming the world so if anything if the
shooter had have read this book he
probably would have done the opposite of
what he actually did so there's that and
also the fact that mine comp is still
available at this store
if Peterson's book is more problematic
than mine Kampf I don't I don't
understand the thinking behind this
because it seems like he's being singled
out particularly because of I guess who
the world says he is because or what a
particular branch of people say he is so
that's just one of the reactions another
reaction is his invitation was rescinded
at Cambridge Divinity School now I have
a degree in Christian studies and I've
watched all of Peterson's biblical
lectures he has about 18 of them up I've
watched all of them there is quite a bit
to be learned from Peterson's take on
the early stories in Genesis that's what
he's covered in these lectures and the
Divinity School could definitely have
learned quite a bit from lectures on
this subject from him so I don't think
that he would have been political in any
way because he's talking he will because
he would have been talking about what
would be specific to the Divinity School
so the Bible I am guessing I don't think
this move makes any sense
and it seems like Peterson is just being
singled out again moving on
something happened actually in my city
in Calgary at the school where my
husband attendance at Mount Royal
University
Armin Navabi was supposed to be speaking
tonight at Mount Royal at an event put
on by the Atheist society and it was
cancelled I'm going to read the tweets
that our men put out explaining the
situation in light of the shooting last
week and the response to the event we
have received from students and staff we
are going to have to cancel hosting your
event with Armin on campus on Thursday
so an atheist wants to have an event at
a school and because of a massacre at a
mosque in Christchurch New Zealand he is
being
asked to not come and speak because of
students and staff having problem with
it
I don't see how Armand's atheism should
be a problem considering that a massacre
happened on the weekend I don't see the
connection Armand is an ex-muslim that
should not have any bearing on whether
he speaks or not he's an atheist and
they were wanting to have an event for
fellow atheists so there seems to just
be a trend of a - to silence any
potential negative feelings from people
who might make certain groups feel
triggered or victimized further I do
think this is the wrong move and I hope
to see that this isn't going to be a
trend in the future but it's something
that I see our society moving towards so
what what is the appropriate response
though in this situation I think the
only thing that we can do rather than
silencing potential triggering people or
problematic people the things that I
think would be more pertinent in a
situation like this is to show the
communities that have been affected love
and support
show your neighbor or your friends
anyone who has a different worldview or
cultural background or belief system or
ideology even be kind to them show them
that you can accept them as a person
even if you don't agree with their
beliefs so that is just what I think
would be the best way to go about
dealing with this rather than cancelling
events and banishing books if you would
like to do some further reading there is
